citeinfo.title: WAC_Flow_Network
citeinfo.othercit: This database was created by Fugro William Lettis & Associates, Inc. for the Alameda County Public Works and Water Conservation District, funded through EOA, Inc.

idinfo.abstract: The lines in this shapefile represent the present-day surface water flow network, including creeks, engineered channels, and underground culverts or storm drains of communities in western Alameda County, California. This database was designed to help the general public and regional planners understand how water flows through western Alameda County waterways and watersheds.
idinfo.purpose: The purpose of this shapefile is to illustrate the present-day surface water flow network within the western Alameda County study area. Elements of the network include creeks, engineered channels, and underground culverts or storm drains. Only larger features are shown. Creeks and engineered channels have a minimum of 0.2 square kilometers of watershed, and culverts or storm drains measure at least 24 inches in diameter. Engineered channels include both natural creeks significantly reinforced by concrete or rock, and artificial channels, ditches, and canals not coincident with a historical creek. Some newer engineered channels are designed to mimic natural channels. These digital GIS files represent the same data as the Creek & Watershed Map of Oakland & Berkeley (2010), the Creek & Watershed Map of Hayward & San Leandro (2010), the Creek & Watershed Map of Fremont & Vicinity (1999), and a portion of the Creek & Watershed Map of Milpitas & Northern San Jose (2005) each published by the Oakland Museum of California. Refinements were made to the creeks and engineered channels to improve registration of the data to aerial photography. Data for areas outside the boundaries of these four maps were added to provide full coverage of the western Alameda County watersheds.

timeperd.current: The polylines in this digital database represent the most current data available at the time of data compilation. If users have concerns that these data are not up to date, they are encouraged to contact the local city government that has jurisdiction ov

idinfo.accconst: This work is public domain and we encourage the public to use the information openly and appropriately.
idinfo.useconst: These data were compiled at 1:24,000 scale and comprise a regional dataset. This dataset is not a substitute for a site-specific engineering study of surface hydrology.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.0.1770

citeinfo.origin: Fugro William Lettis & Associates, Inc. Author : Janet Sowers and Christopher Richard; Digital database prepared by Ranon Dulberg and Jason Holmberg.
citeinfo.title: Creek and Watershed Map of Western Alameda County: A Digital Database

descript.abstract: The lines in this shapefile represent the present-day surface water flow network, including creeks, engineered channels, and underground culverts or storm drains of communities in western Alameda County, California. This database was designed to help the general public and regional planners understand how water flows through western Alameda County waterways and watersheds.
descript.purpose: The purpose of this shapefile is to illustrate the present-day surface water flow network within the western Alameda County study area. Elements of the network include creeks, engineered channels, and underground culverts or storm drains. Only larger features are shown. Creeks and engineered channels have a minimum of 0.2 square kilometers of watershed, and culverts or storm drains measure at least 24 inches in diameter. Engineered channels include both natural creeks significantly reinforced by concrete or rock, and artificial channels, ditches, and canals not coincident with a historical creek. Some newer engineered channels are designed to mimic natural channels. These digital GIS files represent the same data as the Creek & Watershed Map of Oakland & Berkeley (2010), the Creek & Watershed Map of Hayward & San Leandro (2010), the Creek & Watershed Map of Fremont & Vicinity (1999), and a portion of the Creek & Watershed Map of Milpitas & Northern San Jose (2005) each published by the Oakland Museum of California. Refinements were made to the creeks and engineered channels to improve registration of the data to 2009 USDA National Agricultural Imagery Program (NAIP) aerial photography. Data for areas outside the boundaries of these four maps were added to provide full coverage of the western Alameda County watersheds.

horizpa.horizpar: All data should be considered approximate.

procstep.procdesc: This shapefile was created from Freehand files of the published maps and imported into Arcview using a Freehand extension called Map Publisher. The shapefile was then registered to the Stateplane coordinate system using an Arcview Tool called Spatial Adjustment. Data for areas outside the published map boundaries were compiled directly in GIS. Minor adjustment of the data was done in ArcGIS to improve the registration of the data to aerial photography. These data were compiled at a scale of 1:24,000 and will be accurate at this scale. Use of these data at larger scales would be inappropriate as data may appear erroneous when enlarged.

srcinfo.srccontr: Storm drains, engineered channels, and present-day creeks were compiled from city and county data, 2004 to 2009 aerial photography, U.S. Geological Survey topographic maps, and field inspection. A complete list of sources is provided in WAC_Creeks_GIS_Readme_ver.1.0. Additional documentation can be obtained from Janet Sowers at Fugro William Lettis & Associates, Inc. in Walnut Creek, or at www.museumca.org/creeks/.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdefs: Fugro William Lettis and Associates, Inc.

distinfo.distliab: Fugro William Lettis & Associates, Inc. (FWLA) does not assume any liability, responsibility, or make any warranty for the accuracy or usefulness of any information contained in these data or any process associated with the development of these data. These data should not be used for purposes other than that intended during its development. These data should only be used at the scale at which it, or its source documents, was compiled. Use of these data at a scale larger than that at which it was compiled will not result in greater accuracy.
